title: What will China’s GDP growth rate be for the first quarter of 2017 compared to the same period in 2016?
preds: Likely to be similar to previous year but just how accurate or trustworthy are Chinese economic indicaters?

China's economy, the world's second largest, will likely expand 6.8 percent in the first quarter of 2017, the official Xinhua agency quoted a government think tank as saying on Wednesday.

6.8% ( http://www.tradingeconomics.com/china/gdp-growth-annual ) As of today ( 3/5 ) what does China say will happen?
> 6.5% ( https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/china-sets-2017-growth-target-of-65-percent-or-higher/2017/03/04/2b9519e4-013e-11e7-9b78-824ccab94435_story.html?utm_term=.dd09ab62a8af ) When Li Keqiang made a similar statement in March 2016, was he optimistic or pessimistic for that quarter?
Right in middle of range. ( https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-sets-economic-growth-target-of-6-5-to-7-for-2016-1457137605 ) When Li Keqiang made a similar statement in March 2015, was he optimistic or pessimistic for that quarter?
spot on ( https://www.ft.com/content/1bc73e72-c2d7-11e4-ad89-00144feab7de ) How often are there changes of more than 0.3 percentage points from quarter to quarter?
I don't see any in last three years ( http://www.tradingeconomics.com/china/gdp-growth-annual ) I'm going to assume Li knows what he is taking about, that the projection is for a decrease throughout the year and that there is a small probability of dropping .3% points quarter to quarter given the history.

This paper presents good arguments from the human capital development and expansion of education perspective to forecast a mean 3% growth over the next 20 years:
http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1257/jep.31.1.25
"Even  given  the  optimistic  predictions  above,  China’s education levels will be far below these US levels in 2035. Thus, the unlikely hope for 7 percent annual growth in China over the next 20 years would mean that China  would  need  to  have  a  relationship  between  human  capital  and  per  capita  income that is considerably higher than the typical global experience would suggest is plausible"

In the economics community it is reasonably well understood that China make up these statistics.  The lack of variation in these numbers and the timeliness of their release tends to support this notion.  In the past, the best forecasting method has been to chose a number similar to the last number and perhaps add or subtract a little to reflect the trend. I am not aware of any political events or similar which would give politicians incentive to raise or lower their GPD growth figures. The last value was 6.8 but the trend is slowly falling.  I would be very surprised if the figure is outside the 6.5 to 7.0% range.

China simply cannot afford to lower its GDP rate below 6%. The social unrest/hardships, that comes with slower economic growth, is not the only reason why the China/the Communist party would keep GDP rates up, they also know that slower economic growth singnals weakness. Because of India's economic aspirations, the Trump administration, and China's excursions in the South China Seas, amongst other factors, China simply would not want to project weakness.

China's economy is in a depreciating state and the situation is getting worse day by day.
unemployment is increasing

Since 2012 historical GDP growth has rarely been above 7 and more recently even more rarely.  You could reasonably argue that this growth regime since 2012 would persist.  An AR(1) GDP growth model performs well and given recent  market and macro conditions anything far from last month wouldn't be likely. So a base line of above 6.5 and below  7 makes sense. Still, GDP forecasting is wild if reported correctly so a reasonable band around last month should be considered plausible. Since above 7 is considered break neck pace and unsustainable it should be given less weight. But china might have a policy reasons to force it to be above 7 given recent international political rhetoric has ramped up. I would give 7 some weight but not too much given it's china and has a reputation (unfounded or not) of manipulating GDP growth reported numbers.  Below 6.5 hasn't been seen since mid 2009 and recent macro data wouldn't suggest this likely. So,non-zero but very low. Below 6 seems even more unlikely and the government would have bad consequences if this happened.  No data suggests this likely. Even on the chance it does, the government could manipulate the report.  Used this for data.

http://www.economist.com/news/china/21689628-chinas-obsession-gdp-targets-threatens-its-economy-grossly-deceptive-plans  Gave some pause on my below 6.5% confidence but I relied more on data

Coal is currently still the most easily available source of energy. Such aggressive cuts in coal usage seems to indicate that the Chinese leadership plans a managed contraction of the economic growth rate.

Again, this is an important year with the 19th Party Congress in October and Xi does not want negative surprises.  There are certainly possibilities but they would have to happen fast and be significant.

Fudged numbers for political stability and public consumption

Bloomberg median average Q1 2017 forecast is 6.6% with a high of 7.1% and a low of 6.2% according to all the analysts that submit. These are widely considered to be state-controlled numbers and Beijing's target range is 6.5-7%. The number has been inside that range for the past two years. While I think the likelihood is that it prints below Q4's 6.8%, I do not think that the probability is high that it breaks below 6.5%, simply given the need for China to maintain an outward show of strength in response to the Trump administration. I skew slightly above 7% for the same reason.
It's the 6.5 INCLUSIVE part that has me putting a stronger emphasis on my top choice.
China is clearly showing signs of being in the middle of an economic slowdown and demographic and debt pressures will start to take hold.
Their economy was already slowing in 4th quarter 2016, they're backing off on government spending to float economy.
The current forecast is in that range at 6.6%. Who I am to dispute what the Chinese government "wants" to report!
Following the trend here. Playing off the crowd.
Updated to reflect more recent numbers, including in the Economit's itself.

For starters, as a matter of simple math I think 7% growth rates are gone and never coming back. This is because the Chinese economy is much larger today than it was when it grew at 7% and it is much harder to get a huge relative boost at its size, even though as an absolute number the amount of growth today is far larger than it was when the Chinese economy grew faster but it's spread over a much larger economy. As other's have noted, the rate of economic growth in China is a political question. For that reason I think they government will undertake extraordinary measures to keep the economy growing at more than 6%, at least for a while. That said, I think Trump's trade policies are going to hurt the Chinese and I can envision a scenario where the Chinese government allows his trade policies to hurt growth so they can blame an external actor and use the pain to start to pass needed economic reforms in the next couple months.  Given the Chinese governments' (I refer to both the provincial and central governments here) talent for managing (the politest way I can say that)  economic statistics I have no doubt that if the central government demands a growth rate between 6.5 and 7 that most provinces will fall in that exact band, regardless of the reality. If anyone has read 1984 and remembers the rattling off of bogus economic statistics, this process should feel familiar.
I believe a lot of markets follow the pulse of Beijing. I worry they aren't compensating for the slowdown in production, construction and the enormous capital flow outwards.
I think they will make sure they hit their target.

GDP growth in China is a matter of politics, not economics (at least in the short-term). The Party needs to maintain over 6.5% to meet its growth targets, and the Party's legitimacy rests in its ability to reach these targets. Regardless of how much real economic activity is occurring, they will make up the difference with either government spending or "smoothing." Even their head economic minister has been caught saying he relies on measures such as gross electrical output instead of GDP to get a sense of the economy because he doesn't trust their GDP numbers.
Whatever they set as the goal I think they will hit.

Not sure how rigid the Chinese burocracy is, but if I was China I would make sure to pump money in the domestic economy to make sure any Trumpetesque events will have less impact as well as having a nice headline to impress the neighbours.
All indications are that growth is acceleration.  Plus, the government controls the release of any "official" data.
I think China will maintain its current rates but will slow down later in the year when Trump economic policies start taking shape.

Starting point: GDP 4Q 2016 = 7.4%
Next: trend is upwards (7.4 last quarter vs 6.7 annual)
Next: impacts: Trump's "buy American" will lead to reduction in US imports, but not in the first quarter, and I doubt the impact to be of 0.5% on Chinese GDP (and do not forget that China holds the worlds largest USD reserves...)

Forecasts via Trading Economics put China's GDP at 6.7% for this period. Housing price growth is paused at 12.4% compared to the huge growth the sector has seen for quite some time now, while inflation growth has begun to fall slightly, while interest rates have remained consistent for some time.  Inter-Bank lending rates however have fluctuated heavily, with the most volatile period in quite some time, indicating potentially quite a lot of transactions occuring. With this in mind, I will buck the trend (48% confidence rates will be between 6% and 6.5%), and will predict that GDP will be more than 6.5% but less than 7%. This will be my base prediction.
Chinese leadership biggest proponent of free trade at Davos, should enable China to exceed 6% level.

Based on the last growth numbers that we have seen in China and a curve that shows a decrease in growth rates, plus an economy that is showing its difficulties to keep growing so fast, my prediction is 6.7% growth.

I believe the general trend of the Chinese economy is slowing down and the chinese government will set a lower target for 2017. But it probably will not let itself to slow down too much year on year. Probably somewhere around 6.5%.
China will look to manage expectations and move to slower growth in a controlled fashion.

Even given the pressures on their economy and the outside political stresses that may affect them as well, I believe the first quarter of 2017 will be in the 6.5-7% range, after that I think the year will fall to a growth rate of 6.3 or lower%.

Credit stress, shadow banking, structural imbalances, trading uncertainties will affect the growth. Long term the problems will increase. Stimulating the economy through continued infrastructure investments based on increased debt is not sustainable.  Environmental values will increase in importance - this will affect the growth both positively and negatively. Local leadership is relying on reporting high growth to central authorities. Environmental pressures weigh against this growth; however, the significant investments in clean tech outweigh a lot of these effects. Worth mentioning is that the Chinese figures are not reliable in their accuracy.
Highly unlikely to end up in the two outer buckets, but hard to choose between the two middle buckets.

My intuition of China's economic outlook--its proactive global ventures--makes me think that.

general trend: reduced GDP-growth rate, furthermore no big chance of sudden growth while there are many possible challenges ranging from Trumps presidency and a possible trade war, environmental problems like contaminated soil and smog with hindering possibilities for efficiency...

Any numbers coming out of China should be treated with a decent amount of skepticism with regards to how much they reflect the true underlying economy, but even so the overall outlook does not look negative with a strong dollar aiding exports to US (regardless of the domestic currency balancing problems it may bring) with no large Trump effects having time to manifest themselves in Q1, and with demand picking up in Europe, lead mainly by Germany.

I think forecasts from China carry a lot of weight and momentum. If China predicts 6.5-7.0% growth I expect the statistical office to report something similar. I know summed regional reported GPD and China's total GDP have diverged a lot so the official stats aren't that consistent, which means this question is about *reported* GDP not whatever would be reported if their stat office was scrupulous.  Past three quarters have been 6.7% and I expect something similar to happen. Will update depending on what happens when the final quarter of 2016 is released. Will also look out for 2017's official targets. If things go *really* badly then I can see a number below 6 being reported because the stats office can't lie *too* much but I think that would be unlikely. Growth above 7% is possible and would represent a return to historic average but difficult to do at $11,000 PPP gdp per head. Not sure if anybody has done that, so will check and may adjust down.
It's likely to be in line with growth for most of last year.  Any action by Trump will start to have measurable effect in 2H 2017.

With the advent of the leadership summit this year, official numbers will probably be higher than other years. However,  structural tensions have a real chance of blowing up this year in particular due to Trump and "year of the rooster" effects

Chinese Academy of Social Sciences forecasting 6.5% growth full year 2017. First three quarters of 2016 came in at 6.7%, right in the middle of the government's 6.5% to 7% target range. Think >6.5% is most likely, but 6-6.5% is a reasonably close second.

Regression to the mean expected. China is a country with a lot of momentum due to its size and strength.

The reported (not necessarily real) growth will be in the government acceptable range of 6.5 - 7%.  Certain statistics are born of the need to confirm that a government is skillfully and wisely managing things.  Leave the elites in the ruling hierarchy in place in 2017 for 5 more years as they almost astonishingly continue to hit the targets they establish straight on.   How could anyone wish for change in a program like this?

Growth has been pretty solid of late, because of administrative measures, despite the capital flight.  In order to reduce chances of further capital flight, the growth data needs to come out on the strong side of expectations.  A number of between 6.5 to 7% will likely be produced.  No chance they will allow a sub-6% number to print.
